subject: Re: [junit] coverage testing
msgSnippet: Eugene, I can certainly see such a tool being helpful.  However, I would only have it report coverage failures if all the tests pass, I think. David Saff
messageBody:
Eugene,

I can certainly see such a tool being helpful. However, I would only
have it report coverage failures if all the tests pass, I think.

David Saff

Eugene Kuleshov wrote:

> Folks,
>
> I'd like to hear opinions on the idea of raising test failures for
> code not covered by tests right from the tests.
>
> Consider simple class:
>
> public static class Foo {
> public void a() {
> System.err.println("Hellou!");
> }
> }
>
> with a typical junit test case (well, here are no assertions actually,
> but that is not the point)
>
> public static class FooTest extends TestCase {
> public void testA() throws Exception {
> Foo s = new Foo();
> // s.a();
> }
> }
>
> So, one could wrap the above test case pointing to the classes under
> test using special CoverageSuite:
>
> public static class FooTestCoverage {
> public static Test suite() {
> return new CoverageSuite(FooTest.class,
> new Class[] {Foo.class});
> }
> }
>
> That would produce errors like this:
>
> java.lang.RuntimeException: Line 30 is not covered
> at org.something.Foo.run(Foo.java:30)
> ...
>
> These errors suppose to be raised for each uncovered conditional or
> decision branch, which should give a good idea about newly added
> untested code as well as somehow encourage to improve test coverage.
>
> This is not a new idea and had been implemented in Hansel coverage
> tool some time ago. I just implemented a prototype for Cobertura.
>
> regards,
> Eugene
>
